The Commons vote against Amendment 10 to require published assessments of current and future workforce numbers 280 to 219. 

"We are deeply disappointed," says RCP president @bodgoddard. 

See our full statement here: https://t.co/l8fEiksw53 https://t.co/yDG5TNuei0

@paulbristow79 @CommonsHealth @sarahjolney1 @DerekThomasUK @NHS_HealthEdEng Read our briefing on this amendment which sets out more detail about the refresh of 'Framework 15' > https://t.co/kc31hrTivf
@paulbristow79 @CommonsHealth @sarahjolney1 @DerekThomasUK @NHS_HealthEdEng Amendment 10 is put to a vote in the House of Commons. #NHSBill https://t.co/AfldIB6ZcK

@paulbristow79 @CommonsHealth .@sarahjolney1 & @DerekThomasUK speak to Amendment 10. In response to the speeches given across the House, the Minister says 'the workforce is the beating heart of our NHS' and pays tribute to the workforce. Refers to announcement from yesterday on @NHS_HealthEdEng & Framework 15
Conservative MP @paulbristow79, member of @CommonsHealth, now rises to support Amendment 10. Says we need a 'laser like focus' on workforce challenges

@Jeremy_Hunt @Dr_PhilippaW @MGreenwoodWW @RCPCHtweets @APPGC @ToniaAntoniazzi @RichardGrahamUK 'There comes a time when you have to say and vote for what you believe in', says @RichardGrahamUK, confirming he will vote for Amendment 10 to strengthen workforce planning

@Jeremy_Hunt @Dr_PhilippaW @MGreenwoodWW @RCPCHtweets Several more MPs speak in favour of Amendment 10, including @APPGC chair @ToniaAntoniazzi and Conservative MP @RichardGrahamUK: https://t.co/XpVQgzq5cB

@Jeremy_Hunt @Dr_PhilippaW Labour MP @MGreenwoodWW cites the support of @RCPhysicians & @RCPCHtweets for amendment to strengthen Clause 34 of the Health and Care Bill. Conservative MP Andrew Mitchell also rises to support amendment 10, saying the 'whole sector' is united behind this amdnt #NHSBill
@Jeremy_Hunt SNP spokesperson for health @Dr_PhilippaW speaks to Amendment 10. "Workforce challenge is single biggest challenge facing all 4 national health services across the UK" she says

Amendment 10 is supported by a large number of organisations and 6 select cttee chairs, says @Jeremy_Hunt wrapping up his speech. Says "every month that we delay putting in place this structure is a month where we fail to give hope to NHS staff".

@Jeremy_Hunt It's not only about meeting the needs of the NHS workforce, says @GregClarkMP - we need to have extra people who can be the 'brilliant researchers and discoverers of new medicines' in future
The amendment will lead to more doctors, nurses and professionals being trained, says @Jeremy_Hunt - but says that will save the NHS money https://t.co/Vg0DCX0WrK

Hunt begins his speech - 'it takes a long time to train a doctor or a nurse'. Says gov has recognised pressures on NHS by giving additional ¬£, but adds 'extra money without extra workforce will not in the end solve the problems that we want to solve'

@munirawilson We will support the amendment, says @justinmadders and quotes @CommonsHealth report 'there is no accurate, public projection of what health &
social care require in the workforce for nxt 5-10 yrs... without that level of detail, shortages in health & care workforce will endure'
Lib Dem MP @munirawilson says in 2019/20, some ¬£6bn was spent on bank and agency staff. Adds long-term planning to recruit the right skills is 'absolutely critical'

@Jeremy_Hunt Shadow Workforce Minister @justinmadders speaking to amendment now - says sector is united on amendment, and can't find anyone who thinks what gov has put forward as the solution in Clause 34 is good enough

We believe a lack of long-term workforce planning is the main reason behind the rise in unfilled posts.

‚ÄúIt is vital that government commits to a multi-year funding settlement at the spending review to expand the medical workforce.‚Äù 6/6
https://t.co/OMMIYeSqYX

‚ÄúIt takes years to train a doctor, so we need to act now. The RCP‚Äôs report Double or Quits estimates that doubling the number of medical school places from 7,500 to 15,000 will cost ¬£1.85bn annually - a third less than was spent on agency and bank staff in 2019/20. 5/6
‚ÄúThe patient population is ageing, and it‚Äôs expected that 35% of current consultants will retire in the next decade (mean retirement age of 62.5yrs). 4/6

‚ÄúWorkforce is central because it's been a key limiting factor in our pandemic response. We came into #COVID19 with 43% of consultant posts unfilled in England & Wales due to lack of suitable applicants. 3/6

Says RCP president @bodgoddard: ‚ÄúThe financial effects of #COVID19 will be long-lasting in healthcare - increased cleaning, redesigning wards to facilitate distancing and ongoing use of PPE, as well as increased staff absence, and increased patient demand. 2/6

The RCP has added its voice to calls for NHS funding plans made before the pandemic to be refreshed to deal with the costs of #COVID19 and the NHS‚Äô recovery from it. A multi-year settlement is needed to allow expansion of the workforce. 1/6

"If I could ask the government for one thing regarding testing, it would be to have testing within 24 hours for all health and social care workers." says @bodgoddard, rounding off today's evidence session for @AppgCoronavirus.
"However, we can't test our way out of this crisis. It's a useful way to mitigate COVID-19 but it's not the solution."
"If we are to keep people coming to hospital and reassuring them that they are safe, we need to sort out testing."

"Keeping our distance, washing our hands and wearing a face mask are the tools we have to keep #COVID19 under control this winter. If the test and trace app encourages people to do that a bit more, then it's definitely a good thing."
"The workforce is going to be extremely stretched over winter. We're dealing with the normal winter pressures, as well as flu and #COVID19."
"We must continue to keep normal NHS services going for as long as possible this time round."
"At the moment we're seeing sporadic cancellation of elective appointments. We'll always prioritise the urgent cases. This will happen more and more as sickness rates go up."
"At the last evidence session I was asked if I thought there would be a second wave of #COVID19. I said yes, and I think I was in the minority. But sadly I was right."
"At the moment about 1 in 15 doctors are off work, and about half of those are off because they are waiting for a member of their household to get tested."
"88% of doctors were able to get tests within 24 hours in July. This has fallen to 80% as of last week," says @bodgoddard, citing our recent #COVID19 member survey: https://t.co/hZ5ylybbKr
Make sure you're following @AppgCoronavirus from 11:30 this morning to hear our president @bodgoddard giving evidence regarding Test and Trace. üëá https://t.co/F4uXAERQJn

‚ñ™Ô∏è Almost half of respondents (47%) says they‚Äôve been involved in conversations with their organisations about preparing for a second wave of #COVID19, and 90% feel their organisation is at least somewhat prepared for it.
‚ñ™Ô∏è Over half of respondents (53%) said #COVID19 admissions had increased in their hospital over the past two weeks.
‚ñ™Ô∏è Only 80% of respondents who reported having a PCR test for #COVID19 in the past two weeks were able to access the test in the first 24 hours, compared to 88% in July.

Headlines from our survey of RCP members include:

‚ñ™Ô∏è Only 6.5% of respondents were currently taking time off from their usual work schedule. But 40% of them were self-isolating because someone in their household had symptoms and was waiting for a test.

Our sixth survey of RCP fellows and members during the #COVID19 pandemic shows that most doctors are at work, generally feel prepared for the second wave and can access the tests they need. 

But problems do remain.

"For supporting the medical profession, physician associates have been key. Getting physician associates regulated is the next important step that needs to happen."
"We knew we were short of staff before #COVID19 and we've been calling for a doubling of medical school students for the last two years now."
"Retention of staff is one of the key areas we need to work on."
"A lot of the developments for NHS staff that have happened during the #COVID19 pandemic such as a focus on wellbeing, car parking, hot meals - we need all of that to continue."
"We're all incredibly tired and the worry about a second peak this winter is a big one."
"Everyone is worried about what happens in winter. We could have a quiet winter, but we may also have a second wave of #COVID19 coupled with the flu."
"The variability of getting the NHS back on an even keel is often due to whether the speciality is heavily procedure-based or not." says @bodgoddard
